_accidents.ED_Other: no damage, minor employee exposure to liquid NH3

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
. Facility accident release and emergency response policy.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             

1. The management and employees of Gateway FS, Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the VENEDY Fire Department, Washington County Local Emergency Planning Committee or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to to people and the environment.



2. The stationary source and the regulated substances handled.



The primary activity at the facility, which is located at 11019 CO. HWY. 12 is the storage and distribution of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.  The storage and handling system consists of 1-30,000 storage tank, loading risers, associated plumbing and nurse tanks.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.



The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored would be 579,000 pounds, this includes the amount of anhydrous ammonia that could be stored in nurse tanks.



3. This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations. This facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K6-11", published by the American National Standards Institute, Inc. as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administr

ation (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia". Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our employees make up accident release prevention program.



4. Five year accident History



On Thursday, March 31, 2016 a new employee had finished filling the near tank of a double tank rig and was moving to place the hose and valve back in its holding station. The wheel valve was against his left torso and bodily motion appears to have caused the valve to open. The employee's heavy coat and shirt were soaked with liquid ammonia. A small amount soaked through to the employee's skin. The employee treated himself and refused medical treatment. The employee stated that at no time did he feel any burning sensation despite his skin showing signs of exposure. The employee was given time off to recover but returned to work Monday, April 4th, 2016. Follow-up evaluations showed no further signs of distress or injury and the employee has since made a full recovery. A company-wide notice was sent to remind all facilities of proper hose handling techniques.



5. The emergency response program.



The facility has:

-a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;

-provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).



In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the VENEDY Fire Department and WASHINGTON County LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency. Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire department and LEPC.



6. Planned changes to improve safety.



Safety Improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. This facility is now subject to OSHA's Process Safety Management regulations, 29 CFR 1910.119, and all necessary modifications to equipment, procedure
s, recordkeeping and training will be made.  This facility will then re-certify as an EPA RMP Program-3 Facility by the required regulatory deadline.
